results.title: Fast film
results.brief_description: This ingenious cut out animation is the chase film to end all chase films. Borrowing images and characters from various Hollywood classics, ‘Fast film’ then distorts and twists our understanding of where these icons of Hollywood folklore belong. Ultimately mutating into a new narrative where the suave Cary Grant and Frankenstein’s monster happily co-exist side by side.

results.title: Fashions, flowers and favourites
results.creator_credit: Syd Wood, Frank Killian, Tourist Development Authority of Victoria and Movietonenews
results.brief_description: Shows numerous scenes in and around Melbourne (1962?) including activities such as the Melbourne Cup, sailing on Albert Park Lake, eating out and nightlife, the Miss Australia judging, the Sidney Myer Music Bowl and the Royal Botanic Gardens. Commentry by David Low and Bert Bryant.

results.title: Fashions on the field
results.creator_credit: Syd Wood, Frank Killian and Movietonenews
results.brief_description: The 1964 Victorian Racing Club Spring Carnival. Horse racing, fashion shows and fashion on the field. Race commentary: Bert Bryant. Also appearing: Sir Henry Bolte, Sir Rohan Delacombe, Pay Hyland, Miss Australia 1964 and Lord Mayor Curtis.

results.title: Fashions in wool for '61
results.creator_credit: Frank Land and Australian Wool Corporation
results.brief_description: Depicts some of the winners in the Australian Wool Bureau’s Wool Fashion Awards for 1961. The fashions are modelled in various locations around Sydney. Commentary by Leonard Teale; photography by George Heath. The model is Pat Woodley.

results.title: Fashions for Men
results.creator_credit: Mel F. Nichols, Frank Coffey, John Maynard and Department of Information
results.brief_description: Produced by the Department of Information, this government propaganda film shows the manufacture of uniforms in factories for the Australian armed forces serving in the Second World War. The film begins with an opening sequence that chronicles the development of Australia’s armed forces since colonisation in 1788, showing the styles of uniform worn over the decades by soldiers making “glorious history”. The film then explores the mass production and assembly lines of the various equipment required for contemporary uniforms including silk parachutes, khaki wool clothing, brass badges, tin and felt hats, and gas masks. The film is a fascinating insight into factory production of the period, and an example of propaganda encouraging patriotic values in support of Australia’s armed forces. As with many instructional films of the period, the film reflects now outdated gender stereotypes, showing women working in assembly lines sewing on buttons, while men work with steel machinery.

results.title: Fashion: a 'Frost's Century' episode
results.creator_credit: Robyn Wallis, Simon Welfare, David Weiland, Granite Productions and Reuters Television
results.brief_description: A detailed exploration of twentieth century clothing design, documented through extensive archival footage and interviews with numerous fashion identities, including British designer Katherine Hamnett, and editor of British Vogue, Alexandra Schulman. The design analysis contextualises historical, cultural, social and political influences on the development of fashion, and traverses a wide array of subjects including fashion and the war, innovations and trends, fashion designers, the supermodel phenomena and gender differences in fashion and professional modelling. This detailed documentary is presented in four parts. Narrated by Sir David Frost.

results.title: Fashion means business
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “March of Time”.
This film highlights the fashion industry in America. Top designers in New York and Paris are shown at work and a survey of America’s garment district gives some idea of the enormous size of the industry.

results.title: Fashion from start to finish
results.brief_description: Butterick, “Vogue” and “See’n Sew” are together the world’s largest pattern house. The film examines the role of each person involved in the design and manufacture of patterns. An advertisment for “Butterick”, but a fast-moving comprehensive coverage. No other credits. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Fashion daze : Australian style on the catwalk 1910s-1970s
results.creator_credit: National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: Fashion daze is a glimpse of Australian womens’ fashion and style from the early 1910s to the 1970s. Focusing on fashion parades of lingerie, day wear, hats, leisure wear, evening wear and bridal gowns, styles from each decade are presented. Narrated by Lyn Mills.
results.title_for_label: Fashion daze : Australian style on the catwalk 1910s-1970s

results.title: Fasciola
results.brief_description: The life history of a nematode (the liver fluke), showing in detail its structure and its habits. The habits of the snail are then examined and shown to be a source of danger of infection. A detailed study of the life-cycle of the liver-fluke, showing the egg and the first larvae, the intermediate host - a snail, the second larvae, and, finally, the encysted third larvae, which are a source of infection to sheep, cattle, horses, dogs, and humans. The film shows that the most effective methods od dealing with fluke is to eliminate the conditions which are favourable for the breeding of the intermediate host, the snails. A gap is thereby created in the life-cycle of the fluke, as it cannot reproduce without the snails to act as intermediate host to the first larvae.
